div.p: 1. The current general word for weakness of any physical or abstract kind, and of anything including states, persons, and animals is ruò 弱 (ant. qiáng 強 "strong").
2. Léi 羸 (ant. jiàn 健 "strong and healthy") typically refers to physical weakness in humans.
3. Bào 薄 (ant. zhuàng 壯 "strong and vigorous") can refer to a low or weak intensity of something.
4. Cuì 脆 / 膬 (ant. jiān 堅 "strong and hard") refers to physical weakness as a result of brittleness and a propensity to break easily.
5. Chí 弛 (ant. jiān 堅 "strong and hard") refers to weakness as a result of abstract or physical slackening.
6. Shuāi 衰 (ant. shèng 盛 "strong and flourishing") refers to the process of weakening that attends any kind of decline.
7. Hào 耗 (ant. kāng 康 "increasingly vigorous and healthy") refers to the process of weakening that results from using up available resources.
8. Huǎ3n 緩 (ant. jié 捷 "nimble and vigorous in one's effort") is somewhat marginal in the group but can refer to habitual weakness of effort through slowness and lack of urgent and decisive action.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: imbecillitas refers to mental weakness, and a weakness of the heart.
infirmitas refers to bodily weakness, and a moral weakness of character, fickleness and uncertainty.

bibl.title: “荀子”單音節形容詞同義關係研究

sense.def: post-Han: weak, frail NB: in pre-Buddhist times the word refers to lack of courage.

entry.def: Chí 弛 (ant. jiān 堅 "strong and hard") refers to weakness as a result of abstract or physical slackening.

sense.def: slacken, relax; weaken; relax one's efforts
relent on, relax (taxes etc); be lax on (crimes)

entry.def: The current general word for weakness of any physical or abstract kind, and of anything including states, persons, and animals is ruò 弱 (ant. qiáng 強 "strong").

sense.def: that which is weak, a weak state
the weak; a weak person; the weaker party
be weak, frail; be young and weak
show weakness with respect to (or perhaps: be weak as compared to)
to weaken the contextually determinate N

entry.def: Huǎ3n 緩 (ant. jié 捷 "nimble and vigorous in one's effort") is somewhat marginal in the group but can refer to habitual weakness of effort through slowness and lack of urgent and decisive action.
Léi 羸 (ant. jiàn 健 "strong and healthy") typically refers to physical weakness in humans. 3. Bào 薄 (ant. zhuàng 壯 "strong and vigorous") can refer to a low or weak intensity of something.
Hào 耗 (ant. kāng 康 "increasingly vigorous and healthy") refers to the process of weakening that results from using up available resources.
Cuì 脆/膬 (ant. jiān 堅 "strong and hard") refers to physical weakness as a result of brittleness and a propensity to break easily.

sense.def: be weak and easily broken 說文：易斷
brittle> be of weak constitution, get easily broken; be vulnerable
STRIP OF ITS IMPRESSIVE APPEARANCE> make appear weak

entry.def: Bào 薄 (ant. zhuàng 壯 "strong and vigorous") can refer to a low or weak intensity of something.

sense.def: be insufficient in respect to N
be inferior to N, weaker than N

entry.def: Shuāi 衰 (ant. shèng 盛 "strong and flourishing") refers to the process of weakening that attends any kind of decline.

sense.def: declining (LOOK FOR EXPLICITLY INCHOATIVE EXAMPLES WHERE THE GLOSS "DECLINED" IS CLEARLY IMPOSSIBLE)
be in a current reduced state of weakness
LATE: pliable, malleable (also on the inside, structurally)
weak point or state of weakness
have cracks or other week points
be decimated so as to be weakened as a result
be chicken-livered; be fretful and weak
those who have no one to appeal to; the helpless
have no one to turn to (for support)
be emaciated and weak, be worn out
those who are frail because of old age or young age
those who are weak for reasons of high or low age

entry.def: the old and those who are weak from starvation [DS]

sense.def: when one is old and decrepit
be very weak (as a baby at birth)
weaking, someone who is less than a man
be insufficient and weak 膽虛 "weak courage"
be weak in energy: gentle, wispy
those who are less than good
be feeble; be frail; appear weak
weakness, feebleness; pusillanimity; lack of political strength
